1. A 6-year-old male child was brought to the pediatric neurology clinic by his parents due to concerns about delayed developmental milestones and unusually large eyes. The child exhibited bilateral megalocornea with corneal diameters measuring 13 mm in both eyes, significantly larger than age-matched norms. Cognitive assessment revealed moderate intellectual disability, with delays in speech and fine motor skills. He showed hypotonia and subtle facial dysmorphism, including a broad nasal bridge and a prominent forehead. Family history was unremarkable for similar ocular or cognitive abnormalities. Ophthalmologic evaluation confirmed clear corneas without signs of glaucoma or corneal edema. Brain MRI was unremarkable except for mild ventricular enlargement consistent with neurodevelopmental delay. The multidisciplinary team recommended early intervention programs including special education and regular ophthalmologic follow-up to monitor for potential glaucoma development.
